question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If $\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}f(x)$ does not exist and
$\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}g(x)$ does not exist, then
$\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow0}\left(f(x)+g(x)\right)$ does not
exist.
sols:
One common function where $\lim_{x \to 0}f(x)$ doesn't exist is the
rational function $f(x) = \frac{1}{x}$. The same is true for its
negative, $g(x) = -\frac{1}{x}$. Both have a limit of $\infty$ or
$-\infty$ at 0.

However, when these two functions are added together, we get:

$\lim_{x \to 0} \frac1x + (-\frac1x) = \lim_{x \to 0} 0 = 0$

Which is a perfectly satisfactory limit. Thus, these two functions are a
counterexample to this statement, proving it false.

To see an interactive illustration of this solution, see
\href{https://www.desmos.com/calculator/79by0j8hx0}{this page}.
hints:
One way in which limits fail to exist are at vertical asymptotes (where
the function blows up). What would a function with a vertical asymptote
look like? Can you think of other ways in which limits don't exist? What
would an example function look like for these new behaviours?

Is there a way to create a g such that the problems you made in f get
removed?
